one degree of freedom, and an automatic erection system attempts to align its rotor spin axis to the local vertical.

is fed by the flux valve.

A transport aircraft is purchased in Australia and flown to Europe where it will be engaged in commercial operations with a base in Germany. It will be necessary to perform a compass swing procedure because:

options.text: there was a large change of latitude.
the aircraft had to fly through an area of intense Tropical Revolving Storms.
the previous operator had not performed a compass swing procedure within the past 60 days.
the new operator installed new radios.

no reliable navigation signals (from VORs) are being received.

options.text: two torque motors on the horizontal axis.
pendulous internal nozzle on the outer gimbal.

options.text: Heading to fly a Rhumb line track only.

variant.question: A free gyro has the axis of the spinning rotor horizontal and aligned with the geographic Meridian.  If this free gyro is situated at latitude 60°N, the apparent drift rate according to the earthbound observer is:
A directional gyro has...

options.text: horizontal spin axis and is servo controlled in azimuth.
vertical spin axis and is free in azimuth.
vertical spin axis and is servo controlled in azimuth.
horizontal axis and is free in azimuth.

variant.question:
Which of the following statements are correct? A directional gyro is
 
1 a gyroscope free to rotate around two axes.
2 a gyroscope free to rotate around one axis.
3 capable of self-orientation around an earth-tied direction.
4 incapable of self-orientation around an earth-tied direction.
An artificial horizon uses a gyroscope with: (Note: the rotor spin axis is not counted for the number of degrees of freedom of the gyro)

options.text: 2 degrees of freedom and a vertical axis.
1 degree of freedom and a horizontal axis.
2 degrees of freedom and a horizontal axis.
1 degree of freedom and a vertical axis.

1) rotation of Earth.
2) aeroplane motion on Earth.
3) lateral and transversal aeroplane bank angles.
4) north change.
5) mechanical defects.

options.text: the aircraft`s movement over the surface of the Earth.
longitudinal accelerations, and the aircraft`s movement over the surface of the Earth.
the aircraft`s movement over the surface of the Earth, and the vertical component of the Earth`s magnetic field.

variant.question: The indication of the directional gyro is valid only for a limited period of time. The causes of this inaccuracy are rotation of the Earth and...

options.text: the aircraft`s movement over the surface of the Earth.
the aircraft`s movement over the surface of the Earth, and the vertical component of the Earth`s magnetic field.
longitudinal accelerations, and the aircraft`s movement over the surface of the Earth.
longitudinal accelerations, and the vertical component of the Earth`s magnetic field.

variant.question: Apparent drift in a direction indicator is

options.text: 7.5°/hour at 30°N and 30°S, and zero at the equator.
non-existent at all latitudes because of the drift-nut attached to one of the gimbals.
7.5°/hour at 30°N and 30°S, and zero at the poles.
15°/hour at the equator and zero at the poles.

variant.question:
A gyromagnetic compass consists of:

1 – a gyro with its axis perpendicular to the normal axis (the z-axis) of the aircraft2 – a vertical axis gyro3 – a magnetic North detector4 – an erection mechanism to maintain the gyro axis horizontal5 – a torque motor to make the gyro precess in azimuth
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
A directional gyro consists of a:

What options are correct regarding topple and drift of a gyro?
1. Drift relates to the gyro’s spin axis movement along the horizontal plane. 
 2. Topple relates to the gyro’s spin axis movement along the horizontal plane. 
 3. Topple relates to the gyro’s spin axis movement along the vertical plane. 
 4. Drift relates to the gyro’s spin axis movement along the vertical plane.
Among the systematic errors of the "directional gyro", the error due to the Earth rotation makes the north reference turn in the horizontal plane. At a mean latitude of 45°N, this reference turns by:
In an attitude indicator, the gyroscope used has a spin axis which is:

options.text: Horizontal, perpendicular to the lateral axis.
Horizontal, parallel to the longitudinal axis.
Horizontal, perpendicular to the longitudinal axis.

variant.question: The directional gyro is aligned with:

1 Directional gyroscope indicator
2 Rate of turn indicator
3 Artificial horizon
What indications can be displayed on a directional gyro?

options.text: Any heading as required by the pilot.
Heading to fly a Rhumb line track only.

variant.question: A directional gyro is corrected for an apparent drift due to the earth's rotation at latitude 30° S. During a flight at latitude 60°N, a drift rate of 15.5°/h to the right is observed. The apparent wander due to change of aircraft position is:

The indications of the directional gyro as an on-board instrument are valid only for a short period of time. What are the causes of this inaccuracy?
1. the Earth's rotation. 
 2. the longitudinal acceleration. 
 3. the aircraft's motion over the surface of the Earth. 
 4. the mechanical defects of the gyro. 
 5. the gyro's weight. 
 6. the gimbal mount of the gyro rings.
The input signal of the amplifier of the gyromagnetic compass resetting device originates from the:
The latitude at which the apparent wander of a directional gyro is equal to 0 is:
The directional gyro axis spins about the local vertical by 15°a hour:
The characteristics of the gyroscope used in a gyromagnetic compass system are...

options.text: two degrees of freedom, and the spin axis is maintained in the horizontal plane by an erection system.
two degrees of freedom, and the spin axis is maintained in the vertical plane by an erection system.
one degree of freedom, and the spin axis is maintained in the horizontal plane by an erection system.
one degree of freedom, and the spin axis is maintained in the vertical plane by an erection system.

variant.question: Precession in a gyroscope is

options.text: the reaction at 90° in direction of rotation caused by a applied force to the spinning wheel.
the angular limits to which the gimbals may travel before the gyro topples and the indication becomes useless.
the tendency it has to remain in its plane of rotation.

variant.question: The inertia of a gyroscope is greater when:

options.text: Its rotation speed is higher and the mass of the spinning wheel is located further from the axis of rotation.
Its rotation speed is higher and the mass of the spinning wheel is closer to the axis of rotation.
Its rotation speed is lower and the mass of the spinning wheel is closer to the axis of rotation.
Its rotation speed is lower and the mass of the spinning wheel is located further from the axis of rotation.

variant.question:
A directional gyroscope may drift over time due to:1. Rotation of the Earth. 
 2. Altitude. 
 3. Aircraft manoeuvring. 
 4. Aircraft movement over the Earth’s surface. 
 5. Magnetic dip.
The heading read on the dial of a directional gyro is subject to errors, one of which is due to the movement of the aircraft. This error:

options.text: is dependent on the ground speed of the aircraft, its true track and the average latitude of the flight.
shows itself by an apparent rotation of the horizontal axis of the gyroscope which seems to turn at 15° per hour to the right in the northern hemisphere.
is at its greatest value when the aircraft follows a meridional track.
is, in spite of this, insignificant and may be neglected.

earth`s local horizontal by a pendulum.

An imbalance of the rotating mass or frictions in the bearings of a gyroscope will lead to...

horizontally tied and has 3 degrees of freedom.
vertically tied and has 2 degrees of freedom.

variant.question: An aircraft aligns its gyros for departure at location A. At the end of the flight, at location B, the gyros are misaligned by a remarkable angle. What is this an example of? A gyroscope’s:
Why do some gyro instruments topple when the aircraft is placed in an extreme attitude?

options.text: Because the gimbals reach their limiting stops.
Because the air jet hits the buckets at an extreme angle.
Because the wedge-shaped erection device is displaced beyond its operating range.
Because the air supply to the gyro is discontinued.

variant.question: The drift of the gyroscopes of a stand alone inertial system

options.text: induces a position error that decreases along the flight.

variant.question: In a ring laser gyro, the purpose of the dither motor is to

options.text: enhance the accuracy of the gyro at all rotational rates.
